note.body:
[chpe commented while I was proofreading this comment, I fully agree with him, nevertheless, let me please post this comment rather than abandoning it.]

---

As for ligatures, and ligatures only:

Currently VTE offers one single behavior which is a **correct** behavior.

You'd like to have an optional other possible behavior which is visually more pleasing, yet inevitably quite often literally **incorrect**.

(And, by the way, that behavior would not be easy to implement at all.)

So far none of the regular or occasional VTE contributors, nor anyone who could implement this as their debut contribution, have been eager to jump on this. I've painted you a picture about its likely reasons.

---

You mentioned some aspects where Ghostty is better. I haven't tried that terminal yet (haven't actually even heard of it), but allow me please to blindly guess that there are likely a similar amount of features that VTE has but Ghostty doesn't, or VTE does noticeably better.

---

I'm glad you found another project that works great for you. I just don't understand why you want one particular project to be like another one out there. Feel free to use that other one if that's what works better for you. "I love my Emacs, I just wish it worked like Vim" - use Vim then! "I love Chrome, but I'd rather it worked like Firefox" - ... you get the point.

---

VTE is maintained by volunteers in their limited free time, its developers and contributors doing the best they can subject to the time and motivation that they have. Maybe other projects have more resources available, fine. If you're having a problem with GNOME not being modern enough for your needs, in particular with the context of terminals, I'm afraid you're touching much more fundamental problems than just the pure technical bits.

The following is strictly only about me personally, I have no idea how other VTE developers or more-or-less regular contributors stand on this. I used to volunteer a lot of work into this project, I no longer have the motivation to do this. However, I am available for hire (part time) for project works. I'd be more than happy to implement ligature support, in exchange for industry level financial compensation for my work. Let me know if you're interested and you can make such a deal happen.

I don't know what Ghostty (or any other project) does differently, it could be that it happens to have one or more contributors who happen to have a lot of time and a lot of motivation, it could be that they are younger and more passionate than me, it could be that they have fewer family and other obligations, it could be that they have significant funding, it could be that they have developers who can afford not to worry about finances, I don't know. Different project, different conditions, different staff, different goals...

There are surely technical as well as a non-technical (human resources kind of) aspects to this story.

target_title: Support font shaping in terms of ligatures

note.body:
Let's please stop with the advocacy here. You may not realise it, but every comment needs to be read by the maintainers, taking away time from doing any actual work on vte.

Also let's not talk about other issues here, e.g. for images in vte there is work to be done on the SIXEL support (see #253). Similarly for keyboard protocols, etc.

What's needed here is not advocacy, but design first, then coding. Any work here needs to start with a design document carefully discussing all the requirements on ligatures and how they will interact with all the *other* aspects of the terminal. Referencing and discussing other terminal's implementations is necessary of course, but not a substitute to actually solve the *whole* problem.

If such a design (and then the code implementing it) manifests itself, I will certainly review it. What I won't do is copy some other terminal's half-broken implementations (be it ligatures, keyboard protocol, image protocols, etc.).

note.body:
My goal is **not** to tell anybody here to go away from VTE / Ptyxis. I insist. It's to give tracks of reflection for the future of both projects.

I finally tried Ghostty and I suggest authors here to take a look on how they do.
Ghostty is very closed to Ptyxis design. It is fully integrated with GTK4 / Gnome but :

- it has got image protocol support (kitty image protocol), very useful with NeoVim to preview images in project
- it supports ligatures and has the good idea to show the actual char when the cursor is over the symbol
- it's fast and lightweight
- it's integrable like VTE, actually, Ghostty "integrates" their widget in a GTK app, see https://ghostty.org/docs/about#libghostty - the library implement everything (font, rendering and terminal emulation)


Differences with Ptyxis (for whom are interested)

- it supports full-screen + toggling window decoration
- we can set the theme to Adwaita "flat", "raised", "raised-border"... and support others themes
- we can control the padding in the terminal
- the interface is globally the same


I repeat: 

I have no grievance against all of you, against the authors, against the people I'm talking to here. I have a deep respect for the work done by the Gnome project, even if I don't agree with all the choices made (for example, the famous SSD vs CSD debate...).

I'm a developer myself, and I know what it's like to have to manage thousands of lines of code for a project that doesn't please everyone.

But I'm a terminal user, because I develop on NeoVim and I believe that in 2024 a terminal should be able to offer a little more than “rax text monospace”. And I'm an advocate of avoiding the use of “non-standard” software (hence my departure from Kitty).

Ghostty is a fine example of what I like to see in the Linux world. And I hope with all my heart to see Gnome tools and components follow the modernity it offers.

I won't insist anymore. But please understand that this is my passion and affection for Gnome project speaking.

A happy new year to all.

That's not the case, the ligature glyph is a representation, but the editor ask 3 columns for it. The editor sends 3 chars for !, = and =

It's only the "representation" that changes.

target_title: Support font shaping in terms of ligatures

note.body:
One example was, although only vaguely mentioned:

In a certain line of a text file, column 79 contains `!`, column 80 and 81 both contain `=`.

Your terminal is 80 characters wide. You open this file in an editor. The text editor sends `!=` to the terminal and _never_ sends the second `=` character because there's no room to display that.

The terminal, using Fira Code, renders a ligature that has two horizontal lines stacked on top of each other. The desired rendering would be three lines on top, as in the ligated version of `!==`, but the terminal has no chance of guessing that there's supposed to be an offscreen `=` in the file.

If you claim that showing two lines stacked on top of each other, and once the remaining `=` is scrolled in then making it three lines instead is a correct, expected behavior then we have vastly different expectation about the desired enduser experience.

But we could also look at two-letter ligatures such as `<=`. This is supposed to ligate as `≤`, but when partially visible would show up as `<` (or `=` if doing the same story at the left edge of the screen) rather than a `≤` cut in half.

In the non-ligated version it makes perfect sense to me to only see `<` instead of `<=` when the edge of the screen is reached and there's no room for the `=`. But it does not make any sense whatsoever to me to show a `<` when there's not enough room to show the desired `≤`. Or to show a long `=` when there's not enough room to show the desired even longer `≡`.

Maybe we have different expectations here.

note.body:
> It works on Kitty and WezTerm without any problem.

This is not true. Even without trying, I know enough about the overall architecture of terminal emulation that I know for sure that no terminal out there can implement an overall ligating experience without problems. I even proved it, gave you an example. Not even Kitty or WezTerm or anyone else can get it right because the interface between the terminal emulation and the application it hosts wasn't designed to make it possible. Kitty or WezTerm could surely implement _their part_ of the story without any problem, but that wouldn't result in a perfect enduser experience, the interface doesn't allow to fix the remaining cases.

> You probably meant "impossible to get perfect"

Yes, I obviously meant that. And my motivation for implementing something that can't be made perfect or good enough (according to my subjective evaluation) is much lower than for implementing it if it could be made perfect or at least what I'd consider good enough.

It can't be perfect. We may have different ideas of what is or is not considered "good enough". I definitely can't imagine myself being happy with the partial solution that is possible to implement, whereas apparently you would be happy with that.

> we, the users, cannot use ligatures fonts

There are a plethora of terminal emulators out there, each having their own pros and cons. Ptyxis or VTE might be worse here than some others, while hopefully better in some other aspects. There can never be a clear winner. If you're a heavy terminal user with high needs, probably you won't find a single one that fully suits all your needs. It's the nature of the game, pretty much everywhere in the world. You can freely choose which terminal to use, we won't get offended or disappointed or sad if you pick a non-VTE-based one. Pick the one you're the happiest with! Just as you're pushing us to implement ligature support, maybe you can push whichever other terminal to implement whatever you have in Ptyxis but miss in that one. We, VTE developers and occasional contributors, would love VTE to be the one of the best terminals out there, but this cannot mean unconditionally adding every feature that any terminal out there has, nor to volunteer our whole lives for this project. Compromises are made, as in every project, as in every terminal out there, and these compromises are different in each.

(I, personally, have volunteered a lot of time and effort into improving VTE, and I can tell you for certain that I won't volunteer to implement ligature support, I'd much-much rather spend my free time on a bunch of other things, both inside and outside (mostly outside:)) of VTE. This is strictly about myself, I don't know how likely any of the current or future VTE developers-contributors are to implement this feature at some point, and I surely don't want to try to talk any of them out of it. Speaking of which, reminder to myself: stay out of future discussions in this thread :), let them decide when and how to continue.)

target_title: Support font shaping in terms of ligatures

note.body:
It's interesting to me how you're talking about the "little details", and then later mention that ligatures in other terminals indeed come with glitches that you have to accept and you are fine with.

For me, it's exactly those "little details" that tell me I'd rather not have ligatures at all. Because I personally much rather prefer a consistent, glitch-free typewriter-like (i.e. non-ligating) experience rather than one that has an incomplete, inconsistent, glitchy ligature support.

Ligatures in terminals are, by the design of the overall architecture of terminals, impossible to get correct. Imagine you have an 80 character wide window, and open a text file in your favorite editor. In columns 80-81 of this text file there are two letters that are supposed to be connected. But the terminal is only aware of the first one, to be displayed in the last column. It, by design, cannot know what the offscreen next letter would be, therefore necessarily skips the ligature. Or, for 3 character long ligatures (as there are many of them in e.g. Fira Code) it might ligate 2 of them, maybe showing two horizontal lines stacked and crossed out for `!=` rather than three horizontal lines stacked for `!==` because it doesn't see the last `=` sign. Outright incorrect and misleading behavior. You can no longer rely on what's near the edge of the screen.

Or think of those monospace fonts that came up with the utterly braindamaged idea of a single-cell "fi" ligature. What the heck to do there? Lay down the rest of the row 1 column off, breaking vertical alignment, or leave a space mid-word to compensate for that?

Go through the ligature related bugs of Monaspace. There are plenty, plenty of inconsistencies that just cannot be fixed due to the nature of the game. In my eyes it's a disaster.

And then combine this with the aforementioned technical details that make this feature, well at least to the extent it's implementable at all, really not easy or straightforward to implement as there simply isn't a library that we could just pull in that would do this for us, there is no library out there that applies ligatures and yet guarantees to keep aligned to columns as desired. Basically a font rendering engine would have to be written from scratch. Or give up guaranteeing the columns, which would bring in its own additional pile of "glitches".

I find it weird how someone is happy with a necessarily monospace world, yet wants ligatures in that. For me personally, ligatures is pointless in the monospace world. Ligatures is about making the rendering truly beautiful, but in a monospace world you can't do anything to make it beautiful, it's a heavily compromised world in terms of beauty to begin with. In my opinion, in order to achieve full visual beauty we would have to redesign terminal emulation from scratch in a way that allows proportional fonts. And then allows cursor positioning or overwriting parts of an existing text in terms of logical character position rather than visual. And allows cursor movement, text operations regardless of where the line happened to visually wrap to the next row. Many-many things (including ligatures) would become much easier in that world. Alas, given how ~50 years of work has been built up on the concept of a strict grid of characters, this is unlikely to happen. Anyway, I digress, and YMMV.

---

All these being said, if someone comes up with a reasonably clean, maintainable, optional (i.e. possible to enable or disable via API), and reasonably good (within the possibilities of this world) ligature implementation in VTE, I have high hopes that the main developer would accept it. I would definitely not mind it landing in VTE.

The project is running on extremely limited developer resources (as already mentioned), and apparently putting quite a lot of work into a necessarily limited, inconsistent, glitchy ligature experience is just not at the top of our todo lists.

target_title: Support font shaping in terms of ligatures

note.body:
I'm not trying to rekindle a 5-year-old debate, or provoke an argument on the subject. However, I do wonder if anyone here is considering this request.

It's obvious that supporting ligature fonts is not a priority, and I understand that. But it's these little details that make us use other terminal emulators, instead of the one implemented in the official version of Gnome. I'm obviously talking about Ptyxis, which I find superb, but which is sorely lacking in more complete support for “modern” things like ligature support (or images, smooth scrolls, and so on).

I read the comments and I'm surprised by the questions that come up, like here https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/-/issues/192#note_647289.

WezTerm, or even Kitty, don't seem to have that many problems handling it (at least from what I see in the sources), and I think it's not crazy to say that the person who chooses to use a ligature font will have to accept certain “glitches” (I've had some on Kitty, without it being a real issue).

In short, there are certain aspects I don't understand, I'm aware of that, but the management of ligature fonts is still a point that would make VTE really cool.

note.body:
I'd join Pascal's team.

I assume anyone doing anything with this property necessarily looks up at least some "official" (non-VTE) docs about them or some existing uses. They'll almost certainly come across the OSC 9 numbers 1=normal, 2=error etc.

Over here VTE was strongly discouraged against coming up with a competing (non-OSC-9) solution, and it indeed didn't; presumably others won't either. That is, our internal concept is necessarily strongly tied to OSC 9 and this is unlikely to change in the foreseeable future or to be extended to accommodate competing solutions as well.

Even if there's a slight difference between the termprops API and OSC 9 due to its design (0=off isn't a numerical value in termprops but the lack of the property, if I understand correctly) I see no benefit in forcing our termprops API users to use symbolic constants, and confusing them in case they'd rather go with the numbers that they might already be familiar with.

> I don't think they need to match

My opinion is rather: I don't think they should deviate, unless there's a strong reason (which I can't see here).

Anyway, this is just my 2 cents. The current solution is not wrong per se, we just have different opinions in this "why? why not?" question.

target_title: Terminal should scroll to end when switching to alternate screen buffer

note.body:
> I suspect it might happen that the cursor moves to a different visual row but its numerical representation happens to stay the same, and as a result it's not repainted.

I no longer think it's possible. In `vteseq`, the handler of the screen switching escape sequences always does an `invalidate_all()`. An additional invalidation, or lack thereof, due to a semantically incorrect comparison, doesn't make a difference.

However, there's at least one subtle difference that I could fine. Restarting the blinking of the cursor depends on this semantically incorrect comparison.

Open a new terminal, the cursor is in the top row (let's assume a one-line shell prompt). From a different terminal do a `sleep 15; printf '\e[?1047h' >/dev/pts/N` and then quickly switch back to this terminal. The cursor's blinking stops in 10 seconds, and after another 5 seconds (when switching to the alternate screen) it doesn't restart. Repeat with `l` to switch back to normal screen, it still doesn't restart. Again with `h` to switch to the alternate screen whose `insert_delta` is 1 now instead of 0 (don't ask why) and suddenly the internal representation of the row isn't the same across the two screens, hence blinking is restarted.

And my patch above doesn't fix it either because I'm still performing this semantically invalid comparison :-) Similarly, calling `invalidate_row(row)` is harmless but semantically incorrect after a screen switch because `row` is relative to a different number than expected.

Roughly something like this...

[vte-2850.patch](/uploads/d14db5b4d5bd812f8cfdd303bc034aa9/vte-2850.patch)

It incorporates the inlined "quick and dirty fix" of the previous comment just to make it more explicit and maybe more robust, but works without it too.

I ended up not using the destructor, as we need to emit signals after the things I do from `finalize()`, so I decided to explicitly call that `finalize()` and thus the destructor wasn't needed. Or we could use a brace-block to make `context` go out of scope there.

There are a few other places as well where the code could look slightly different, e.g. rename `finalize()` to `flush()`, or to `flush_and_reinitialize()` and thus make it automatically call `initialize()` again, these are minor details; let me know if you're okay with the overall approach but would prefer any such minor tweaks.

I've just barely tested the patch with the reproducers shown above; it needs more heavy testing to make sure nothing breaks (e.g. invalidation rectangle tracking). Aiming for `master` only; if a backport is desired then IMHO that should be the one-line "quick and dirty fix".

target_title: Terminal should scroll to end when switching to alternate screen buffer

note.body:
A quick and dirty fix is

```
                 update_insert_delta();
-                if (m_scroll_on_output || context.m_bottom) {
+                if (m_scroll_on_output || context.m_bottom || m_screen == &m_alternate_screen) {
                         scroll_to_bottom();
                 }
```

Looks like we never snap the alternate screen's scroll position to its desired place. The only thing we have is this piece of code here responsible for auto-following, that is, if we were snapped to the bottom previously then we keep it snapped to the bottom (regardless of the "scroll on output" setting). This, combined with the user not being able to scroll away, is supposed to guarantee that once snapped to the bottom (as initially the alternate screen is) it'll always remain this way.

Except that it goes wrong if the previous state was checked on the normal screen.

---

There are probably some other obscure inconsistencies as well. My theory is that you can probably do this (haven't tried) with some wait between the steps except where noted:

- produce more than a screenful of text
- disable scroll-on-output
- scroll back
- switch to alternate screen
- enable scroll-on-output
- in a single step:
  - switch to normal screen
  - produce some output
  - switch to alternate screen
- disable scroll-on-output
- switch to normal screen

and you would notice not being scrolled to the bottom, although it should (and would if we inserted some pause even where we didn't). That's simply because the snapping logic doesn't notice the quick back-and-forth switch to the normal screen where data was emitted.

---

Digging a bit deeper:

Not sure if other aspects that we track in `ProcessingContext`, e.g. bounding box tracking, also potentially suffer from similar issues.

The overall approach is at least semantically incorrect, as code segments like `if ([...] (context.m_saved_cursor.row != m_screen->cursor.row))` might compare the old screen's cursor row (relative to its origin) against the new screen's cursor row (relative to its different origin). I suspect it might happen that the cursor moves to a different visual row but its numerical representation happens to stay the same, and as a result it's not repainted.

I guess this line in `post_CMD()` is super relevant:

    // FIXME m_terminal->m_screen may be != m_saved_screen, check for that!

I guess upon a screen switch we should "flush" the knowledge we gather up and re-initialize the state. I think it would go something like this:

Most of the current constrcutor of `ProcessingContext` would be moved to a normal "initializer" method, only setting `m_terminal` would remain in the construtcor. The constructor would of course call this initializer method.

Most of what we do in the bottom of `process_incoming()` would go to a normal "finalizer" method of `ProcessingContext`. The destructor would also call this.

The FIXME line would be replaced by calling the "finalizer" and the "initializer" methods if the screen switched, effectively flushing every todo we gathered up so far and starting anew.

note.body:
So my conclusion after reading through this issue, the windows terminal issue/pr, and conemu implementation, is that while this API has flaws and might be improved, it's reasonably widely implemented, and small enough (and the flaws small enough) so as to make it not worthwhile to try to invent yet another protocol for this.

Therefore I'm going to commit a patch to support `OSC 9 ; 4` to vte (plus hook it up in the test app). I've changed it a bit since the last wip/progress branch; please check and test if this still meets the requirements. The parser at least should fully copy conemu behaviour.

target_title: Implementing the Kitty keyboard protocol

note.body:
FYI, I'm fairly certain the win32-input-mode protocol doesn't need more than 16-bit parameter values. It's a direct mapping of the [`KEY_EVENT_RECORD`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/key-event-record-str) structure, which only uses `WORD` values (the `dwControlKeyState` is a 32-bit `DWORD`, but I think only 9 bits are used). And Windows Terminal itself only supports 16-bit parameter values, and it needs to parse this protocol itself.

For characters outside the BMP, Windows generates two "virtual" key presses with the surrogate pair codepoints. In that situation the virtual key codes and scan codes would be 0.

ETA: Thinking about this some more, if you actually had a keyboard that generated supplementary characters, it's possible you would get non-zero vk codes and scan codes for those surrogate pair characters, but I've only ever seen them generated via something like an IME, and in that scenario the key codes have always been zero. Not that this is relevant to the 16-bit issue - I just don't want to be misleading anyone about the other protocol details.

target_title: Implementing the Kitty keyboard protocol

note.body:
kitty's protocol also uses integer values of unicode code points as part of CSI sequence. If we do not allow it, we will be unable to implement kitty's protocol also:

`CSI unicode-key-code:alternate-key-codes ; modifiers:event-type ; text-as-codepoints u`

https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/keyboard-protocol/

target_title: Implementing the Kitty keyboard protocol

note.body:
There is no limitation in ECMA-48, but vte applies a limit of 16-bit values. (DEC had an even smaller limit.) So even if vte itself won't parse this sequence since it's sent to the host, it shouldn't emit a sequence that violates its own API contract.

I guess we could just not emit anything if the value isn't in the BMP.

note.body: As for 65535 limitation: where comes it from? I can't find any mentions of such limitation in standards. Generated sequence will be sent to application, vte will not parse it. How can any limitations be applied?

note.body:
Some code/protocol comments:
```
+		normal_length = g_snprintf(NULL, 0, "\x1B[%i;%i;%i;%i;%i;%i_",
+			vk, vsc, gdk_keyval_to_unicode(event.keyval()),
+			event.is_key_release() ? 0 : 1, cks, 1);
```

This assumes that gdk_keyval_to_unicode(event.keyval()) never returns a character outside of the BMP. If that happened, the value would be > 65535 and thus outside the allowed value range for CSI parameters in vte.

```
+	// - create state for the English layout
+	struct xkb_rule_names english_names = { .layout = "us" }; // Specify English layout
+	xkb_data.keymap = xkb_keymap_new_from_names(xkb_data.context, &english_names, XKB_KEYMAP_COMPILE_NO_FLAGS);
```
Is hardcoding the "us" layout mandated from the win input protocol, or is that your choice?

```
+	if (!xkb_data.keymap) {
+		g_error("Failed to create XKB English keymap");
+	}
```

No g_error() allowed in vte. If this fails, the input protocol just should be disabled.

Also the code in `Terminal::widget_key_release()` looks wrong to bypass the input method and storing the modifiers. Consider that the DECSET mode may be enabled/disabled while a key is pressed but before it's released.

```
+XkbData xkb_data = {0};
+gboolean right_ctrl_pressed = false;
+gboolean right_alt_pressed = false;
```
No global state is allowed. Everything needs to be per-VteTerminal.

Also, you have some TABs in the patch.

note.body:
So, here's a fun twist. A year after this discussion, in Matrix spec v1.10, the `<font>` tag with `color`, `data-mx-bg-color`, and `data-mx-color` attributes was deprecated... in favor of a `<span>` tag with `data-mx-bg-color` and `data-mx-color` attributes. (You can see the updated spec at @Mis012's link, above.)

So, they're no longer even trying to pretend that Matrix formatting is HTML-compatible, and keeping the `<font>` tag around for Matrix compatibility is no longer a particularly solid argument.

> So I guess we could conclude that the minimum enforced value (10) is a Windows Taskbar UI hack, and should _not_ be considered part of the `OSC 9;4` spec, right?

Yeah, I think that's a reasonable assumption. I'm sorry my wording was misleading, but I was looking at it from the point of view of someone trying to emulate ConEmu's behavior exactly as it appears, because that's what we were doing in Windows Terminal. If you're using a different representation for those error states then that minimal value quirk does seems pointless.

> The unfortunate inconsistency with `9;4;2` and `9;4;4`'s last parameter being interpreted conceptually differently if it's `0` versus `1`..`100` still remains.

Yeah. Personally I think this aspect of the ConEmu behavior is worth matching, but it wouldn't be the end of the world if you chose to ignore it. I'm willing to bet there are other implementations of `OSC 9;4` that have got this wrong the same way we did in the initial WT implementation.

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
So I guess we could conclude that the minimum enforced value (10) is a Windows Taskbar UI hack, and should _not_ be considered part of the `OSC 9;4` spec, right? (Still, arguably it should be the Taskbar implementing it and not ConEmu/WT, but that's not my problem.)

> `9;4;2` [...] and `9;4;4` [...] if the active value was zero it uses a minimal value

I guess this was a bit sloppy wording on your side, wasn't it? The old active value doesn't matter, and it's not only `0` for the new value that undergoes this restriction. A minimal value of 10% is always enforced in these two major states ("error" and "paused"), no matter how you got there. Correct? But, again, it's Windows only, we don't have to (and IMO shouldn't) care about it.

---

The unfortunate inconsistency with `9;4;2` and `9;4;4`'s last parameter being interpreted conceptually differently if it's `0` versus `1`..`100` still remains. I guess we have to live with it, any change in behavior would likely cause _some_ apps to misbehave.

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
> > I just checked our source, and it looks like we set it to 10.
> 
> Where is that? (I couldn't find in ConEmu.) I mean: in which component: ConEmu, WT, or the taskbar?

I found that in the WT source. I haven't look at the ConEmu source, but I've tested it, and it looks to be approximately the same.

> It's the taskbar making the decision to use different colors for the bar; it could just as well decide to use some icon for error/paused, or have a thin frame of the desired color around the yet-to-be-occupied part of the progress bar, etc.

It could yes. And if you're using a progress indicator where you don't have the same constraints as Windows, you obviously don't need to concern yourself with that issue. I'm just explaining why it works the way it does on Windows.

> If there was a way to query the value (there'll be in VTE if we use termprops), would it report 10?

We don't have a way to query the value, but semantically I think it makes more sense to report it as 0.

> If there was a way to switch back to "normal" state without changing the percentage,

There isn't really, or at least not in a way that you would notice. `9;4;1` will set the percentage to 0. `9;4;3` doesn't show the percentage, so you can't tell the internal state. `9;4;2` and `9;4;4` would leave it unchanged, but that is no different from setting it to 0, since they both have the "minimal value" requirement.

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
> I just checked our source, and it looks like we set it to 10.

Where is that? (I couldn't find in ConEmu.) I mean: in which component: ConEmu, WT, or the taskbar?

If it's in the taskbar then that's fine. It's the taskbar making the decision to use different colors for the bar; it could just as well decide to use some icon for error/paused, or have a thin frame of the desired color around the yet-to-be-occupied part of the progress bar, etc. If it chooses a UI that cannot (or can hardly) differentiate between x% normal and x% error for small values of x, I guess it might be somewhat reasonable (although is surely questionalbe, might be misleading as well) to depict 10% error as a workaround. And then it's done equally for every app: terminal or not.

Or is it in the emulation part? If there was a way to query the value (there'll be in VTE if we use termprops), would it report 10? If there was a way to switch back to "normal" state without changing the percentage, would it remain on 10? I can't express with words how bad that design sounds to me, designing the behavior and semantics of the abstract concept of progress bar to work around the limitations of one concrete representation on the UI. I truly hope it's not this.

> People have been happily using it all this time, flaws and all.

Yeah, I'm really not too happy to see that we should copy something as simple as a progress bar that isn't flawless.

> If you're so disgusted by the implementation that you can't bear to have in included in VTE

That's not what I'm saying. I'm sure chpe and chergert will complete this feature, I don't want to stop them. I just couldn't help notice these problems / undocumented corner cases / bad design choices etc.

target_title: greater compatibility with macOS 11.0 for arm64 and 10.15.1 for x86_64

note.body:
[I'm not familiar with macOS, nor VTE's macOS compatibility, so this is a generic response. The project's main developer will correct me if he disagrees.]

People have successfully built VTE on macOS for many-many years. Even when macOS's version was 11.0 or 10.15 or even lower.

Therefore I presume that you would also have success with building a somewhat older VTE.

Generally, we tend to aim for a roughly maybe around 1-2 year gap between VTE's version and the underlying system's version, but there have been exceptions (if it was justified) when the gap was much smaller (e.g. if I remember correctly, VTE 0.76 required a GTK version released at the same time).

macOS 13.3 was released a bit over 1.5 years ago.

It's not a project goal to support older systems, older VTE versions can always do that. For newer VTE versions the focus is on new features, code cleanliness, improved performance etc., sacrificing compatibility with older systems if that's what it takes.

If you ran into a compiler error, at least please show us what that error was. If compilation was explicitly rejected due to your system being old then probably there was a good reason for that. Nevertheless, if there's an easy and non-intrusive fix to support older systems then a patch would probably be accepted.

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
> (Note how the enum description at the top is incorrect or outdated, revealing that state 4 was probably a later addition.)

It was. When Windows Terminal first discussed implementing this, someone complained that the sequence was missing support for the paused state (since it was known that the Windows taskbar was capable of that), so we asked ConEmu if they would be willing to add that and they did.

> What is that "minimal value" (both the concept and the actual value)?

I just checked our source, and it looks like we set it to 10. I think the reason for this is because you've got a change of state that the user needs to be aware of (something has failed, or is paused awaiting user input). These states are indicated by a different color in the Windows taskbar (red for 2, and yellow for 4), but you wouldn't see that color change if the progress is still at 0. Thus the need for a minimal value.

> If the progress bar is expected never to retract (which is not necessarily true for all the progress bars out there in the world) then it would have been equivalent and much simpler to just always set the given value.

I don't necessarily disagree, but we actually got a bug report from some application that was dependent on this behavior, because we originally didn't realise it was supposed to work this way. It's definitely something people are using.

> Or am I overthinking???

Yeah, I think you are. It's an existing sequence that's been around for over a decade. People have been happily using it all this time, flaws and all. If you're so disgusted by the implementation that you can't bear to have in included in VTE, you could always invent your own sequence, but nobody is going to thank you for making them support two different sequences for the same thing.

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
If I'm not mistaken, the relevant code for this is not the parser, as linked by chpe, but that `DoSetProgress()` eventually ending up at https://github.com/Maximus5/ConEmu/blob/740b09c363cb16fbb730d72c53eaca1c530a016e/src/ConEmu/RealConsole.cpp#L13656 .

(Note how the enum description at the top is incorrect or outdated, revealing that state `4` was probably a later addition.)

Indeed, state `0` forces the percentage value to be 0, state `1` sets the new number (if omitted then 0, this was handled in the parser).

State `3` always ignores the additional parameter (or lack thereof) and leaves the value unchanged. (This mode is for a "spinning wheel" to denote progress when we have no clue about the percentage.)

> `9;4;2` [...] and `9;4;4` [...] if the active value was zero it uses a minimal value

I don't understand that. What is that "minimal value" (both the concept and the actual value)?

What I see, by reading (possibly mis-reading) the code, is: First, if the value is omitted then the parser handles it as if it was zero, so there's no way to distinguish these two cases further down the line. Then if the value is larger than 0 then it's set as the new value; if the value is 0 (or omitted) then the old value stays in place. There's no special-casing for when the old value was 0, there is special-casing for when the new number is 0.

---

Side note:

I can't help but notice how bad the design is for the omitted/zero value at states `2` and `4`. It's semantically a nonsense; it's hard to use correctly and easy to use incorrectly.

If the progress bar is expected never to retract (which is not necessarily true for all the progress bars out there in the world) then it would have been equivalent and much simpler to just always set the given value. After all, it's one single application controlling the progress bar, it knows its percentage, being able to leave it unchanged across a state change (rather than having to re-specify the same value) is not a needed feature.

If the progress bar can retract (as the app gets more info and notices that it underestimated the remaining amount, or if interactively more tasks are added to the queue) then you can't jump back from "1%" to "0%" and go into "error" or "paused" state in a single step, it has to be two consecutive steps; although you could have done it in a single step from "2%" to "1%" or any other higher values. Very easy to write incorrect code that almost always works correctly, except at those very small numbers. The correct code either requires branching on the actual values (a sign of bad design: who on Earth would want to do that?); or has to take the code path which works with all numbers, i.e. to set the new value first and then in a separate step switch to the "error" state, in which case the dual behavior (the actual behavior depending on the concrete number) of the design is pointless.

It's a "feature" which is tempting to be used, but whenever used, is almost certainly used incorrectly. It's a "feature" which any reasonably simple implementation of the fully correct behavior necessarily has to avoid. It's an absolutely pointless and harmful complication on what could (and should) have been simpler and better.

---

Speaking of design, one more dilemma:

What is supposed to happen if the operation is complete? What do existing apps that use this feature do? What is systemd about to do?

I guess the main use case is when the given terminal is not in the foreground, so that in its tab / title / the taskbar etc. I still get to see how it's going. But what should happen if the operation is done?

The app immediately removing (resetting) the progress bar would remove it from the UI, I guess. It would not draw my attention to something that's been completed and is ready to take new input from me. It's okay if the use case is that I simply want to make sure that there's no pending operation (e.g. it's safe to suspend the laptop, all files have been uploaded or whatever), but not if I want to follow up with further steps.

So I guess the app would have to keep it at 100% until... until what? Until the next user interaction, I guess?

Wouldn't it be desireable to have a "ready" state which the UI can display in a completely different way, e.g. with a green tick?

Or is the numeric value of 100 that's supposed to behave this way? Therefore I guess it's part of the design that the emitter app is supposed to round all percentage values downwards, rather than to the nearest integer? Is it documented anywhere? Or is it supposed to be common knowledge about progress bars?

But wait... if it's an interactive app that completed an interactively given command then it could surely do this. But if it's a simple command that exits after completion? It has to clean up after itself, so the only reasonable thing to do is to remove the progress bar. So, should maybe the terminal decide to keep the progress bar visible at least until you focus that terminal? Should interactive apps therefore also follow this pattern and remove the progress bar as soon as it's completed? If so, does it or does it not make a difference if they skip the value of 100%? Or, if it's supposed to be removed immediately, what's the point of the value 100?

Or should utilities that exit after completing their task leave the progress bar active? Should the terminal perhaps offer some means of dismissing it (e.g. by clicking on it)?

(Mind you, I haven't yet checked the behavior of ConEmu or Windows Terminal, nor any utility using this feature.)

---

Is there anywhere a sort of a design doc, big picture doc, a "this is how you're supposed to use this feature" document?

Is there anywhere a doc that goes down into all these details that I'm nitpicking?

Or am I overthinking???

target_title: Implement OSC 9;4; for progress tracking similar to windows terminal

note.body:
For some additional context, I think this sequence was intended to be a wrapper around the Windows taskbar progress indicator, so that's where the different states came from. See here:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/windows/win32/api/shobjidl_core/nf-shobjidl_core-itaskbarlist3-setprogressvalue

And on the subject of the percent parameter, I found it easier to understand if you think of it as four separate operations with different requirements:

* `9;4;1` sets the state to "normal" with an optional percentage value in the range 0 to 100 (defaulting to 0 if omitted).

* `9;4;2` sets the state to "error" and `9;4;4` sets it to "paused", both with an optional percentage value (defaulting to the active value if omitted, but if the active value was zero it uses a minimal value).

* `9;4;3` sets the state to "indeterminate"; there is no fourth parameter.

* `9;4;0` turns the progress indicator off, and also resets the percentage to 0; there is no fourth parameter.

Although note that ConEmu is the reference implementation. If their behavior differs from the Windows Terminal implementation, that should be considered a bug on our part.

note.body:
Some links:

[ConEmu doc](https://conemu.github.io/en/AnsiEscapeCodes.html#ConEmu_specific_OSC)

[WT issue](https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/3004)

[WT PR](https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/pull/8055)

[WT followup](https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/9960)

[WT doc/tutorial](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/terminal/tutorials/progress-bar-sequences)

---

First impressions, without having thoroughly read through the above links (and more):

Essentially, the parts that we care about: `9;4;0` means to remove the progress bar, `9;4;1;x` means to show a progress indicator (bar? numeric value? I guess it's up to the UI) at `x` percent.

The third digit can also be `2` ("error"), `3` ("indeterminate"), `4` (sometimes "paused", sometimes "warning" -- which??). It's unclear to me whether they are mutually exclusive to `1`, i.e. remove the progress bar and display something else instead; or whether they set some additional state (and in that case how to remove that additional state while preserving the progress). `2` and `4` can take an optional parameter, unclear to me what its meaning is.

Whereas a progress bar, without any additional semantics, is a concept seen at many places and thus I find it a nice idea to add to terminal emulators, I can't see the justification of the additional modes. They seem to be way too specific, unclear to me why every app out there who needs a progress bar would be happy with this set of additional states. Also unclear to me why any such additional state have to be associated with a progress bar; why couldn't someone who has no progress bar notify about an error or warning or paused state?

I'm personally not happy with the choice of using a percent value. Given today's UIs, screens etc. it might be desireable to draw a much smoother bar, if information is available to the emitter app. The UI could e.g. round the visual description to "[integer]%" but keep the actual bar move in more fine-grained steps. But that's what we have, I guess.

There's quite some confusion around as the choice of OSC 9 conflicts with some other terminals, I guess I've seen Kitty and iTerm2 mentioned who do notification or something similar. I don't know how these were resolved, or whether we'd be okay to jump on the WT and systemd wagon here.

Again, not a big deal, but in case you're interested, I just tracked down the original Unicode proposal for `U+2426` which explains the intended usage:

https://www.unicode.org/L2/L1998/98353.pdf

> The upright reverse question mark is used by DEC VT terminals to indicate that an invalid code was received. It also stands for SUB and/or RS in Wyse 370 [G2] and VT220 [A1] display controls mode, and is a glyph in its own right in the DEC Technical Character Set [C2], the DG Special Graphics Character Set [D4], and several others. This one is not in Unicode at present, but is encoded in Amendment 18 to ISO 10646 at the code point shown, with the requisite shape of reverse upright question mark.

target_title: What to print for the 0x1A (^Z) byte

note.body:
You should display something like a `▓` or `␦` character.

Quoting STD 070, p5-132:
> The `SUB` control is used to indicate the presence of characters in the data stream for which there is no graphic representation. This control is processed by placing a reverse question mark in the display at the active position. Most existing terminals (VT100, VT101, VT102, VT125, VT131, VT132) display the blotch character instead of the reversed question mark.

The other interesting one is `CAN`, which was originally treated as an alias for `SUB` on some of the earlier VT terminals, but was later changed to display nothing - it just serves to cancel a control sequence. Quoting STD 070, p5-129:

> If received during an escape or control sequence, the sequence 
is immediately terminated and not executed. No character is displayed.

target_title: What to print for the 0x1A (^Z) byte

note.body:
ECMA 48:

> 8.3.148
> SUB - SUBSTITUTE
> Notation: (C0)
> Representation: 01/10
> SUB is used in the place of a character that has been found to be invalid or in error. SUB is intended to be introduced by automatic means

VT520/525 programming manual:

> Substitute SUB 1/10
> Immediately cancels an escape sequence, control sequence, or device control string in progress, **and displays a reverse question mark as an error character**.

(emphasis added).

So I think vte's behaviour is correct.

target_title: Strong flickering when dnf downloads data

note.body:
Duplicate of #2837.

See detailed analysis over there (with two different utilities though, plus a link to a Red Hat bug where the same reporter reported this about `dnf`).

This is a bug in `dnf`, not in VTE. A brief (possibly much shorter than the UI refresh cycle) back-and-forth change of a character cell, if requested by an application like `dnf`, may or may not end up being shown on the display. While it might happen that you see frequent flickers in VTE and have not yet seen any in Konsole, it just means their internal timings of processing the data is different and the bug is much less likely (but not impossible at all) to surface in Konsole. But it does not mean that VTE is buggy by any means. You could test many more terminal emulators and find flickering in quite a few of them. And you could easily find a plethora of utilities that can update their UI in VTE without flickering.

Please report to `dnf` developers that they shouldn't even momentarily erase the contents that they are about re-populate with near-identical data, they should just overwrite the old data in place.

target_title: Inconsistencies

note.body:
A much simpler reproducer is `echo -n the quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog`. The issue is not specific to VTE, you'd see the same in other unrelated terminals as well.

If the output of a utility doesn't end in a newline, it messes up the subsequent prompt and command line in `bash`. This is a well-known issue with `bash`, with probably no reliable and cross-terminal solution that `bash` could use out of the box as workaround.

Preferably, specify an output format to `dnf` (or whichever other utility) that ends in a newline.

If a command has already been run and the new prompt doesn't start in column 1, you can just get used to pressing Enter to get a new prompt.

VTE beginning with version 0.76 (and a few other terminals out there) supports the unofficial "conditional newline" escape sequence which is `\e]133;L\e\\`. Emit this from the beginning of your prompt: it's a newline if the cursor is not at the beginning of a line (more precisely: beginning of a possibly auto-wrapped multi-line "paragraph"), and a no-op otherwise. Embed it between `\[` and `\]` for `bash` to correctly compute the columns, as it's required by `bash`. See `/etc/profile.d/vte.sh` (or whichever similar filename that your distro ships it with) for a commented-out example, you can simply uncomment that one line (and make sure that your distro is set up to `source` this file from your interactive shells) if you'd prefer this behavior.

note.body:
The patch is not okay (yet).

Those `\0` bytes in the string do match some regexes, e.g. the `.` wildcard for any character, `.*` for any string, etc. That is, a match can still span across multiple neighboring non-OSC-8 runs, causing conflict and confusion at the separator OSC-8 cells.

Now, maybe g-t doesn't have any such regex (I'm not sure), but other terminal apps might.

It was stupid from me to think that `\0` would magically refuse to match anything. We really need a solution for regex matching to only be performed on the extracted contiguous runs of non-OSC-8 cells.

For this, the above patch might be a good starting point, in order not to have to reimplement (duplicate) a slight variant `get_text()` from scratch, nor to have to do the painful matching between the string and the attributes array. But then regex matching will have to manually split this string at `\0`s and run individually for each component.
****

note.body:
> Maybe confine the regex matching algorithm to contiguous runs of non-OSC-8 cells, thereby preventing overlaps in the first place? I guess this could be the simplest and cleanest approach (automatically addressing bug 1 as well).

I went with this quick and easy approach.

[0001-widget-Make-regex-matching-avoid-explicit-hyperlink-.patch](/uploads/db8ed68e34ef2bdc7df10dcc0d99be90/0001-widget-Make-regex-matching-avoid-explicit-hyperlink-.patch)

I'm not entirely happy with the low-level text extracting method receiving a new flag for the this very exact special need of the regex matching code. I think a generic text extracting method, and some follow-up quirks would generally be nicer. But we already have flags about whitespace preserving. Also the external follow-up tweaking, based on a deprecated array of a very few attributes (only including the basic colors and maybe two arrbites out of the many, definitely not the hyperlink), and having to match the offsets between the strings vs. the attributes array sounds truly painful.

The magic trick of replacing hyperlink cells with `\0` bytes guarantees that the preceding and following segments aren't glued together to a false positive. That '\0' in the middle of the string isn't mistakenly taken as the end of the string, onscreen hyperlinks are still detected fine even if they're followed by an explicit OSC 8 hyperlink in the given row.

Check the behavior in a couple of other terminals that frequently flicker with current `ollama`. Just to prove to yourself that the behavior is not specific to VTE.

Record the output using `script`, and play back slowly, byte-by-byte using the aforementioned `slowcat`.

VTE parses the received data in the given order (no lookahead or shuffling the order of instructions). After each letter or escape sequence it updates its internal idea of which cell contains which character, as well some global properties like the cursor's visibility. Every now and then it paints that state on the UI. I'm absolutely certain that it doesn't paint the cursor at a place other than the desired position, and it doesn't paint the cursor if it's set to be hidden. We're talking about code as simple as "at the very beginning of the method that paints the cursor: if the cursor is set to be hidden then return". How could this go wrong?? Any such bug would be hard to introduce, and we'd surely have received reports about permanent incorrect behavior then, not just transient flickers.

Please trust that VTE is doing what it needs to do.

I'm sorry but I won't get involved in debugging `ollama`, `lips`, `node.js` or any other similar software, let alone work-in-progress modifications of them. It's up to you, or the developers of those software to figure it out.

note.body:
Unfortunately it's not possible to make the cursor entirely flicker-free.

The cursor traverses through all the characters that are re-printed (except for certain clearing and scrolling sequences), and if for whatever reason a UI update occurs in the middle, the cursor is not at its expected location.

Hiding and re-showing the cursor, a trick also seen in `ollama`'s output, mitigates it to some extent: it won't flash up at places it's not expected to, but it still might briefly disappear at its desired location. With command line prompts it's hardly ever noticeable, since operations that change the contents but leave the cursor at place are not typical at all.

For a progress bar, as in `ollama`, a 100% robust solution can be to completely hide the cursor for the entire duration of those progress bars. After all, you don't need a cursor then. Just make sure that if the application ends abruptly, e.g. via Ctrl+C or some other signal, then it quickly re-enables the cursor before quitting. For a prompt, like in your `lips` REPL, this is obviously not feasible: you need to show the cursor since it acts as the input cursor.

Emitting the change in an atomic step surely reduces the chance of a final flicker, as per my previous comment. If you're lucky enough that no-one splits that single write later into several smaller data fragments and the terminal also handles it as one, then it won't flicker. The more extra hops you have in the middle, like networking, ssh etc., each might add their own chance of splitting into two or more consecutive smaller blocks, thus slightly increasing the risk of a tiny flicker.

---

I can think of a few more cases when a flicker is unavoidable.

One is combining characters (like non-spacing combining marks (NFD accents), spacing combining marks, VS16 emoji selector etc.). Here receiving the base character first, followed by the combining or emoji selecting character slightly later, might cause the first one on its own to be rendered momentarily. For this, I blame Unicode's design for placing the combining accents after the base character rather than before.

Closely related is ligatures (not supported by VTE) and Arabic shaping: The first character(s) might briefly be displayed in their non-ligated or non-properly-ligated / non-properly-shaped form.

A completely different one is BiDi: on top of the regular emulation behavior there's a layer that visually shuffles around the characters. Here all sorts of completely different shuffling can happen with partial data.

---

At one point there was a proposal for an escape sequence for atomic (flicker-free) updates. I don't think there was an agreement how it should look like, and I don't know if anyone went ahead and implemented anything. But it's still just a hint, it can't be a mandated escape sequence; if the closing counterpart is lost for whatever reason then the terminal would never update anything, that's not good. The goal was to be a hint for the terminal to wait for a little bit longer before updating the UI. But, again, I don't know if any terminal added support for something like this.

---

For your use case, combining accents and BiDi probably don't matter. The best is to combine both methods that you asked about previously: fix the escape sequences so that the basic text content is guaranteed to be flicker-free even if the data is replayed slowly, and aim for an atomic write of the entire update so that the cursor's flickering is also much less likely. Also combine with hiding and showing the cursor if you wish to.

This is about as far as you can get with avoiding flickers, and it should be pretty good in practice.

note.body:
The only 100% reliable solution is to rework the escape sequences. Please (if you're attempting to fix this bug) let this be your primary goal.

The stream should, with a tiny delay inserted at any point, still produce flicker-free output. (Note: there's a `slowcat` utility in VTE's source which can insert a tiny delay after every byte, should you wish to experiment with slow playbacks.)

---

What's the problem with "printing everything at once", if that "everything" contains clearing the line and then reprinting it?

---

First, before the data actually leaves the application:

How do you know that it really prints everything at once, i.e. atomically??

Your best bet is to use low-level functions such as `write()`. Theoretically it can result in a short write, in which case you have to retry with the remaining bits, and thus it's no longer atomic. [Update: now that I think of it, I think it can only happen in non-blocking mode which you're unlikely to have enabled. [Update 2: I was wrong, short writes can also happen in the default blocking mode if the output channel is clogged and a signal arrives.]] In practice, since you only write small amounts of data into the tty channel and the terminal emulator keeps draining it, you are pretty safe.

Or maybe you use higher level stdio functions, such as `[f]printf()`. Do you know how they work _exactly_, when do they promise to resort to a single `write()` and where can they break it into multiple ones? At least, at `\n` they probably flush, i.e. break into multiple `write()`s.

Maybe you figure out that `printf()` works with 4kB buffers (it's an example only, I'm not sure this is the buffer size), and flushes whenever it's full or at `\n`. But is surely won't become full with 200-ish byte progress bar updates, right? Well, very silly example, but maybe one day someone decides to produce rainbow-colored progress bar, each character having a different RGB color, that's 20-ish bytes of escape sequence per character, combined with a 200-column terminal can extend that 4kB buffer, causing a break at an unexpected location.

Maybe you find the low-level yet convenient `dprintf()`. Do you know how it works, in terms of multiple small writes vs. fewer bigger ones? I don't.

Maybe it's all written in some different programming language (I haven't checked), using C++'s `cout` and `<<`, or whatever solution Rust or Go or Python or any other programming language offers. How familiar are you with the exact details of those?

It definitely requires deep knowledge about the printing functions of the programming language to be (almost) sure that whatever you think you print in a single step is indeed printed as a single step by that function.

You can verify the behavior with `strace`, but that doesn't tell anything about what will happen if some buffer gets filled up, or on other platforms. It's an observation only, not a promise.

---

Second, what happens after the data leaves your application?

The kernel sometimes needs to modify the data, e.g. convert `\n` to `\r\n`. How does it do that? Can it insert breaking points there, or anywhere else? At https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/-/issues/2627#note_1724632 we were really surprised that reads from a tty are often short reads, returning fewer data than already available there. Why? I don't know. A bug in the Linux kernel? Could be. Can it happen anywhere? Can it happen if the buffer always has at most 200-ish bytes? I don't know.

What if networking is involved, let's say, old-fashioned `telnet` or `netcat`? Various transport layers have their maximum packet size, e.g. I think it's around 1500 bytes on ethernet. Does it mean that a single step of sending 3000 bytes might easily arrive at the remote party as two consecutive 1500-byte reads? I don't know, possibly.

What if `ssh` is involved? Do you know how _exactly_ the protocol looks like, and the sending server and the receiving client work? I don't. Is it possible for them to break the stream at some location? Is it possible that on the server `ollama` prints 200 bytes in a single step, yet the local ssh client prints 100 bytes followed by another 100 bytes in a next step? I don't know.

What about `screen` or `tmux`, can they split at unexpected places? I doubt, but maybe.

What about accessing a virtual host, like `lxc shell`? There must be some component forwarding the terminal data. Can they split it at places you wouldn't expect? I don't know.

For some of these, you can probably prove that they cannot split. For some, maybe it's extremely unlikely to split at random places. For some others, maybe it's not even that uncommon.

---

Third, what about the terminal emulator?

A single-threaded one is extremely unlikely to deliberately split an input package and update its UI in the middle.

A multi-threaded one might happen to do this. I haven't taken a look yet at any multi-threaded terminals, but I bet they need to have a mutex between the input processing-parsing thread and the display updating thread, to prevent concurrent access to the buffers (and thus the displaying thread seeing inconsistent and changing data there). If the scope of this mutex is the entire package received as input in a single step then there's no problem. But if the scope of this mutex is smaller, if the scope is individual instructions that modify the buffer, then updating the UI can kick in at the middle, i.e. taking a snapshot when (sticking to ollama's example) the bottom row is empty.

---

There's a lot of unknown here, and a lot of extremely unlikely and maybe some reasonably likely scenarios that eventually might add up, and I'm quite sure that at least rarely, for a few users out there, with their complex setups, there would be occasional flickers.

Such a solution would almost certainly be a massive improvement over the current situation, hopefully making flickers very rare, but could never be 100% perfect.

note.body:
If I beef up `VTE_CHILD_INPUT_PRIORITY` to `G_PRIORITY_HIGH_IDLE` (100) (instead of its current value `G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE` (200)) then the amount of flickering noticeably decreases, to about its half, which is still way too much.

In turn, updating the display becomes laggy if large amounts of input is processed.

Note: We keep installing an uninstalling a tick callback that drives the UI updates. I guess we have to uninstall it so that the process doesn't wake up 60 times per second if otherwise nothing happened. The tick callback goes with `GDK_PRIORITY_REDRAW` i.e. `G_PRIORITY_HIGH_IDLE + 20` i.e. 120.

---

What happens currently in VTE:

- GLib main loop notices that input is available, thus calls `io_read_cb()`.
- `pty_io_read()` tries to read a large-ish amount, reads 44 bytes.
- It tries to read a bit more immediately, but there's no more data at this point. (This retry is irrelevant for this investigation.)
- It processes those 44 bytes, and installs the tick callback to start regularly updating the screen.
- By this time, the next 144 bytes may or may not have arrived, it doesn't make a difference. The higher priority tick callback is invoked by the main loop, which redraws the canvas (with an empty bottom row).
- Now the next 144 bytes are available. They are read and processed.
- (So far all these steps combined took much less than 1/60 seconds.)
- 1/60 or so seconds later the tick callback is called again, redrawing the canvas (this time with the re-populated bottom row).

If I modify `VTE_CHILD_INPUT_PRIORITY` to be higher (as in: lower numerical value) than `GDK_PRIORITY_REDRAW` then the following changes:

If those followup 144 bytes arrive while processing the first 44 bytes then the main loop will decide to also process these followup 144 bytes before redrawing the screen. Thus no flicker. A little bit larger window was available for those bytes to arrive on time. But if those 144 bytes still haven't arrived then the display is updated, resulting in a flicker.

---

What I guess we _could_ (but I don't think we _should_) do in VTE is: Whenever we decide to install the tick callback, don't actually install it straight away but install it with a tiny, heuristical delay, let's say 1/120th of a second (half of a screen refresh cycle) later.

The drawback would be: The average latency, as meticulously measured by Ivan in #334 and the linked blog post, would increase by exactly this amount.

Also, the chosen delay would be absolutely arbitrary: the higher the number, the more flickers are avoided, but also the higher the latency becomes. The lower, the more flickers would remain. I doubt there's a magic number that would be a good compromise: would work pretty reliably with all these broken apps to filter out the vast majority of their flickers, yet not cause an unwanted amount of delay.

That said, we _could_ maybe experiment with some low values, e.g. around 5ms, to see how much it impacts usability vs. how much it reduces flickers. But I'm still not happy about the idea of increasing latency in _all_ the apps out there, just to _mostly_ work around some bug in a _few_ broken ones.

---

Another possibility to consider, involving GTK work too:

As far as I know, the tick callback is not just a repeated 60Hz callback at any random times, but is somehow synchronized to the monitor's refresh cycle / vsync or whatever it's called.

Apparently not the first invocation, though, after installing the tick callback. That one happens ASAP (respecting the priorities) from the main loop.

What I guess we'd need is a new feature in GTK, telling not to rush with the first invocation but to wait for the first vsync, i.e. call it at a time when it would be called anyway, had it been installed for longer.

Not sure: does it make sense??

Or would _this_ noticeably increase latency, in cases when the redraw is so quick that currently with a decent chance it still makes it into the frame that's already being rendered by the monitor, and thus would be delayed by a frame with this change?

I don't know, we'd need an expert on this area to comment on this idea, which I am definitely not.

---

I still hold my opinion that not only the proper, but also the simplest fix is to fix all those apps out there that emit flickering updates.

note.body:
> How about my Node.js REPL [...]

In our warm-up conversation in #2815 I was already pretty certain that this was a problem with the emitter apps. After all, if an application does not touch a certain character cell, there's no way VTE on its own will begin to flicker it.

Then here I analized your `ollama` output and gave a clear proof that it was indeed a problem with this app.

Now you're asking about `lips`. The tiny output you posted is absolutely clear: the cursor is moved to the first column, then ED (Erase in Display) `\e[0J` erases everything to the cursor's right in the cursor's row, as well as all the lines below. This does include the `lips>` prompt. Then the prompt is re-printed. Just like with `ollama`, there's clear proof here that your utility asks the terminal to erase your prompt and then re-display it later. It does ask for a brief flicker (which may or may not end up on the UI in form of pixels, depending on how processing the input, updating the pixels, and the monitor's refresh cycle go relative to each other).

I cannot tell from the information you've given (lack of timings and whatnot) why the flicker happens with certain keypresses and not with others; nor do I feel like further debugging obviously broken apps, sorry.

> I understand what you're saying that the "fix" should be done in those apps. But why this should happen if it worked perfectly fine before and suddenly only in one Terminal it's "broken".

It's not true that the overall behavior is only broken in one terminal. You yourself have already said that you're facing occasional flickers in xterm. And you did not answer my question: If you're bothered by these flickers, why would you happily settle with a solution that has fewer of them, why don't you aim for having none at all?

A recent change in VTE, by pure accident, made it more obvious that these broken apps are indeed broken. It's nothing unprecedented here, the world of software development is full of examples when an unrelated change happens to reveal a bug elsewhere. (For example, this very scheduling change of VTE happened to reveal a long-standing and previously extremely rare bug in VTE's scrollback buffer handling, which we had to locate and fix -- and of course fine-tuning the new scheduler's parameters to hide that bug was not an option.)

A change (_not_ a newly introduced bug, but a new behavior which is just as correct as the previous one) in VTE coincidentally happens to make some bugs of some other apps more prominent. Work on getting those bugs fixed, please.

> I don't think that it's feasible to fix this in Node.js

Why not? The bug is there, not in VTE.

> Yes Node.js will also need to make a breaking change just to "fix" a "bug" in VTE.

What breaking change??? They currently produce broken output, output that does request a flicker. They need to fix it, to produce an output that does not request a flicker. That's not a breaking change, that's a fixing change.

> The reason why I think the issue should be "fixed" in VTE is because it introduced a breaking change, and it's a single project responsible for that breaking change. It's easier to fix the issue in one project than fix hundreds of them that may be as difficult as fixing VTE.

There are three things here I'd like to mention.

First, again, new VTE isn't the first where this bug occurs, it's just perhaps the first where it's quite prominent.

Second, I think you might underestimate the cost of "fixing" it in VTE. It's not just a simple fine-tuning of a parameter, or a missing one-liner. The scheduler would have to receive presumably fundamental changes. Reverting to the old one, with much lower frame rate and much higher latency, is not an option. We'd need to find some solution that is as effective performance-wise as the new code, plus provides a workaround here. I think that modifying VTE's behavior to please these broken apps is significantly harder than changing some escape sequences and shuffling around some printfs in a few dozen of such broken apps. But maybe I'm wrong. Anyway, it's irrelevant, because:

The third thing is: It doesn't matter which one is cheaper. It's not the cheaper (in terms of developer cost) or quicker (as in: implemented the sooner the better) fix or workaround that developers have to go for. Developers have to go for the fix that is the architecturally correct one, the fix that results in the cleaner state of things (no nasty workarounds, heuristics, second-guessing what that other party wanted to say rather than what it actually said, but doing in the first place what you really want to do), the fix that works not 99.999% but 100% of the time. And that "fix" just cannot be that apps request for a flicker and all the terminals out there fully reliably eliminate them. The fix is for these apps not to request a flicker.

Please focus on getting those apps fixed (at least file a bug against them; but it sounds like an easy warm-up task for any new contributor that I presume you yourself can also fix with reasonable effort in any of them).
