note.body:
> The problem with this is that a lot of apps would need to be updated.

Let's update those lots of buggy apps, then. I don't see a problem with this.

The fix to them is extremely easy. It's along the lines of emitting a `\e[K` (clear to the end of the line) after printing the updated line, rather than a `\e[2K` (clear the entire line) before printing the updated one. I.e. slightly changing and shuffling around a few `printf()`s, or alike. The amount of work is measured in minutes. Maybe an hour, but that includes all the boilerplate of manually testing on a wide variety of terminals, unittests, code review, and whatnot.

(Note: care has to be taken that if an entire line is printed then `\e[K` wipes out the last character on most terminals (not on VTE though). If an entire line is printed then this sequence shouldn't be emitted. It's recommended to leave the last character of the row out of this game, as in the example you provided, so that the cursor doesn't interfere with the contents, and also so that `\e[K` works as expected.)

Contrary to this, "fixing" VTE might require heavy modifications to VTE, beginning with having to understand how its big picture with processing input goes. If I were to do it, I estimate it to take multiple days, possibly over a week to understand the code and refactor without regressions. I am personally extremely unlikely to do it, as I'm no longer active in the project wrt. nontrivial tasks. The two Christians on the project are much more familiar with that area of the code and could certainly do it quicker than me, but a few recent problems there (during the aforementioned big refactoring of 0.76 and having to track then down) showed that they're not 100% fluent with that code area either, I assume it wouldn't be a trivial task for them either. I cannot tell how they prioritize this "bug" and how likely they are to work on it any time soon.

Fixing a few dozens of apps that produce flickery output is presumably much smaller amount of work than working them around in VTE.

Also note how I'm referring to "bug" and "fixing" VTE in quotes. VTE is not broken. Whatever it does in response to the received input, is absolutely legit. It's not the ideal behavior, it could be improved to please such apps, but it's not broken per se by any means.

> The problem with this is that a lot of apps would need to be updated. From what I see, it's common to clear the line, write new content.

I can't recall off the top of my head ever encountering such behavior from an app. Look at all the software out there that could be considered as reference. Shells (bash with its readline, and others), screen drawing libraries (most notably ncurses), popular utilities that do their own screen drawing (vim, emacs, less, top...) all show that this is _not_ how to update the screen.

> And in case of my small project LIPS, I would need to fix the issue in Node.js itself, and it will not flicker only in latest version when it will be merged.

How is it any different if a workaround goes into VTE? Then you'd also need to wait for the fix to be created, released, and make it into your system. The lifecycle of how an update arrives at your system is not a pro or con for the fix to go into either component.

The fix (or maybe workaround) needs to go into whichever component(s) it belongs to in the long run, not whichever component could ship that fix (or workaround) quicker to you.

> And fixing those tools, so they work on new version of Terminals that use VTE, sounds odd.

Using the word "work" here is harsh and unjustified. They do work in VTE. There's an annoying flickering, but other than that, they're fine.

You know what's odd in my book? In my book it's odd to not acknowledge if a piece of software is broken and fix it over there, but instead expecting another software to work it around.

You are annoyed by this flickering to the extent that you started tracking down the relevant component and reported it. I can totally understand that. What I cannot understand: How come you could be satisfied with a solution that noticeably reduces the amount of flickering, but doesn't completely eliminate them? Because it's clear that no matter what VTE would do, there would still be some flickering remaininig. You yourself also say at https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2322799#c7 that xterm also flickers. If I were you, and if I were personally annoyed by these flickers, I would want _all_ of them to be gone.

VTE cannot fully fix the problem, nor can any other terminal. VTE could, by putting a significant amount of work into it, mitigate the problem, but it would still remain to some extent. It's much simpler, easier, cleaner, cheaper to fix the actual buggy emitting apps.

---

While at it, back to the analysis of the problem for a sec.

Initially (while the progress bar only has a single Unicode character at each end) an update consists of 188 bytes. Such an update is sent out once every 0.1 seconds. The 44th byte of this string is a `\n`. Clearing both lines and repainting the first line happens before it, repainting the second line happens after it.

In the emitter app, it's probably 187 bytes, with `\n` being the 43rd; a preceding `\r` is inserted by the kernel's tty line discipline.

As seen in the timings, the newline is often a breaking point: `script` stopped receiving input there momentarily. This is probably due to the emitter app using line-buffered stdio (although that wouldn't explain the breaking point at offset 3012, so I might be wrong with line-buffered stdio here). Also I'm not sure if the kernel is any likely to insert a breaking point at `\n` where it inserts the preceding `\r`, I doubt but I cannot exclude this.

While not clearing the text that's about to be overridden is the desired solution, not pausing at a linebreak would go a long way and would presumably mitigate the problem probably to similar extent than any terminal could. So even if the app insists of using this pattern of clearing the line first, it could rearrange the segments so that the line is cleared _immediately_ before re-populating it (most importantly: with no newline in between), and/or use direct non-buffered writes to not have an implicit flush at the newline character.

The emitter app sends a bunch of instructions, including to clear the bottom status line; and a tad bit later (in a separate followup package) sends another bunch of instructions, including to re-populate that bottom status line with its updated contents. You expect the terminal to recognize this situation and not to paint the intermediate state. I firmly disagree with your conclusion. It would be a nice-to-have, but not an expectation from any terminal.

Even if the two instructions were sent in the very same package, there'd be no guarantee that an underlying component (kernel, networking, ssh, tmux, whatever) couldn't split them with some delay in between, or some terminal emulator itself (especially a multi-threaded one) couldn't take a snapshot and render the contents between those instructions. The chance of getting a flicker would become much lower, though.

The only 100% robust solution for an emitter app is not to clear the cells that are subsequently re-populated with similar (or identical) characters. Sending out the clearing and the re-populating instructions in a single step presumably gets you _almost_ there, with very few flickers. Sending them in two consecutive steps: no, just don't do that if you want a flicker-free experience. Just don't.

---

Please repeat the analyzing steps that I performed for the other apps that you also have a problem with, and file a bugreport along with the analysis (also linking to this bug if you wish to) against them.

target_title: Visible re-renders when content of the lines is updated

note.body:
`timing.log` is a bit hard to read manually. Obviously each line is a time to wait (in seconds) and the number of bytes to print. The header line of `session.log` is excluded.

In order to make it more readable, I modified the file using this script to include the absolute offset of `session.log` where the data fragment begins. The header line's length is hardcoded.

```
#!/bin/bash
offset=110
while read a b; do
  echo $a $offset $b
  offset=$((offset+b))
done
```

Its output goes like

```
0.888364 110 18
0.010993 128 28
```

meaning to wait for 0.88 seconds, then from offset 110 print 18 bytes, then wait for 0.01 seconds, then from offset 128 print 28 bytes etc.

This can easily be examined together with `session.log` in any text editor that displays the cursor's offset in bytes.

---

Looking at `session.log`, almost every line goes like:

- print "pulling e554... 0% [progress bar] [speed]"
- show cursor
- (note: according to the timing log, this is where a 0.1 second delay occurs)
- hide cursor
- clear the cursor's line (`\e[2K`) (!!!)
- go to column 1
- go 1 row up
- clear the cursor's line (another `\e[2K`) (!!!)
- go to column 1
- print "pulling manifest"
- carriage return (go to column 1)
- linefeed (go back to the bottom row)

Absolutely, absolutely clearly the emitter app produces data that is supposed to flicker. It clears the text before overwriting with the new one. It should overwrite without clearing, and only clear the parts that are meant to be cleared.

Any terminal emulator, upon its own discretion, might at any time pause reading its input and go ahead and update its display, and after that resume processing input. It's the nature of this game. And of course multiple terminal emulators will behave differently; one might be better in some aspect (or for some apps), another might be better in some other aspects (or for some other apps).

To make it worse, VTE doesn't just randomly, out of thin air decide to pause reading. There _is_ a delay in its input at points where the status line is erased. According to the timing log, the data often stops momentarily, for a tiny-tiny fraction of a second, at an offset that's the beginning of a line of `session.log`, i.e. the beginning of the loop as shown above. At byte offset 1151 for 0.000089 seconds, at byte offset 1339 for 0.000223 seconds etc. VTE happens to update its UI at these points. At these points the bottom row is meant to be empty, that's what the emitter app asks from the terminal emulator.

Absolutely clearly a bug in the emitter app.

---

That being said...

I guess there's room in VTE to improve the heuristics of when to update the canvas or when to read more data from the pty. After all, it pretty often decides to update the canvas when some data is pretty much immediately followed by more data.

Maybe the algorithm could be modified so that in case of such tiny delays between two chunks it would continue consuming input, i.e. it would process the next pretty much immediately available piece of data.

The way we hook up to the GLib main loop to watch the file descriptors, the frame clock to do the UI updates, the cooperation between multiple VTE widgets for each of them to play fairly (a part of the code that I never managed to understand), combined with making sure that throughput doesn't regress significantly, and let's also mention #200 here...; it might not be easy, or feasible at all, to implement it; I can't tell.

Anyway, implementing this would make it significantly less likely for a flicker to appear, but could never entirely eliminate it. It's the emitter app's responsibility to simply overwrite previous text without erasing it first, it will never flicker then.

---


> This is a regression, it was working few months ago.

VTE version 0.76 received significant architectural changes hereabouts, resulting in a higher display refresh rate (60Hz or I guess whatever your monitor's refresh rate is, compared to its earlier 20-40-ish Hz), thereby also a much lower latency, and also an about 2x throughput. This might have also had an effect on when VTE decides to continue reading its input and when it decides to update its UI.

I'm really not sure which step you exactly refer to as flickering. The download phase, e.g. at "13/93", where the bottom of the output goes up by a few lines? Seems like it's the intentional behavior of `dnf` when it reports the progress of multiple parallel downloads. Or the installation phase where the bottom row is sometimes empty for a short period? Again looks to me that's what dnf asks it to display, it probably completes the previous line (with a newline) and then waits for a little while before filling up the new line with data. The "lips" prompt? We have no idea what that app does, but shells and apps using the readline library show you how to implement a flicker-free prompt.

I see absolutely no evidence of VTE doing anything differently than what it's being asked to do.

Can you try some terminal emulators that are _not_ based on VTE, preferably some modern fast ones, and confirm the same behavior there?

Looks to me like a "bug" (or at least unfortunate, unpleasant behavior) in `dnf` as well as your in-house app.

What changed in VTE recently, in version 0.76, is that it's faster than it used to be and updates its canvas more frequently. This could be a reason for any such flickering to be a bit more visible to you. Previously VTE updated its canvas approximately 20-40 times per second (I don't know how frequently exactly). Newest versions update them according to the monitor's refresh rate, i.e. typically 60 times per second, maybe even more frequently. If an app asks to clear the bottom row, and about 1/60th seconds later asks to populate it with new data, then yes, you are going to see a flicker. It's a problem with that app.

(Oh, and again, it's totally offtopic here, unrelated to what this very bug is about.)

Backspace problems

note.body:
No, that's unrelated.

The two direction of terminal emulators (sending keypresses to the app, and rendering the received data) are absolutely independent.

This bug here is about what to send when the user presses the Backspace key of the keyboard.

Your problem is about the other direction: what to print based on what an app sends. In particular, if an app asks to remove a line and a bit later asks to paint it with new contents (or maybe re-paint it with the previous contents), you'll obviously see a flicker. If the emitter app doesn't insert a delay then still a delay can occur due to other circumstances.

If an app wants its output to be flickerless, it's that app that needs to make sure that it doesn't wipe out the contents just to re-paint them shortly afterwards. It should print the new contents, overwriting the previous ones, without any step in between. You'll have to file a bugreport against those emitting apps.

Or, if scrolling is involved, like printing the same one-liner over and over again in a loop (e.g. the command `yes lorem ipsum`), this flickering in the bottom row is essentially unavoidable: at any time it's possible that the terminal emulator has only processed a partial line, and therefore the rest of that line is still empty, when it comes to updating its display.

But at least if the given app, let's say `dnf` in order to update a few lines of scrollbars, prints a reasonable amount of output in a single `write()`-like syscall then such flickers will be quite rare.

> I'd be interested in how other projects are solving this "meson subproject needs to be checked out but there is no network access" problem.

I was really surprised by this architecture the other day, i.e. the `meson` step checking out a repo.

I'm not familiar with `git`'s submodule feature, nor with `meson`'s best practices, but I would have expected `git` to automatically check out that other related project (submodule), too, and that `meson` would have nothing to do with it.

Not sure if `git` can do this automatically, or there's an additional step required after the main `git clone` or alike to check out the subrepos, but still, having to do it "manually" (via another `git` command) sounds a bit better to me than a `meson` step doing it. I'd expect `meson`/`ninja` to work fully offline, and I'd also expect `meson`/`ninja` not to modify anything outside of the build directory.

Also not sure what to do with the tarball, i.e. whether to include this subdirectory there or not, and if not then how would building from a tarball go.

Another possibility is not to use any subproject thingy, but to copy those files into our repository (assuming it's permitted by its license).

Referring back to #2823, I still think that

> unwanted skew in the accepted inputs between normal vte and vte on libc++

is not that bad, it might not be worth the price of this whole `fast_float` hassle to cope with that.

Indeed the package corresponds to upstream `fast_float` repo's v3.9.0, dated Jan 2023. I think it's okay if we need a newer version, but then I think we should prefer the bundled one and reject the system version (or check that it's new enough). No idea how much work that is with meson/cmake.

---

Taking 1 step back:

It's a header-only library that jumped 3 major versions in less than 2 years. Header-only means that it probably doesn't have to worry _that_ much about backwards compability than a runtime-linked one would have to, dunno. Anyway, I'm somewhat worried about its future robustness.

Just wondering: isn't there a completely different, more robustly widely available solution? Like, good old-fashioned `atof()`/`sscanf()`? :) We're getting into a ridiculous amount of build system complexity and way too many problems for the supposedly simple task of parsing a number (where I assume we don't need the speed, nor the accuracy (like rounding to even) that this library provides).

I'm stupid.

The Gsk (gtk4) version is okay. `flush_background()` is passed a `bg_area` parameter that correctly takes the per-cell vertical offset into account.

The problem is with the Cairo (gtk3) version where `begin_background()`/`flush_background()` are no-ops and the actual painting is done by the now-cell-based `fill_cell_background()` method.

One possibility is to do a local `#if VTE_GTK ...` business here, which we do at so many places... to call `fill_rectangle()` in gtk3 and `fill_cell_background()` in gtk4, rather than having virtual/overridden methods that are a no-op in Cairo.

note.body:
(Just very-very remotely understanding the Gsk API...)

I guess `begin_background()` could take and remember the sub-cell offset in pixel.

Then `flush_background()` would need to cleverly compute the stretching parameters (if, hopefully, the API is clever enough to perform cropping if necessary). Or if not then this trick of stretching a bitmap (where each cell is represented by a single pixel) should only be applied for the fully visible cells, and partial rows on the top and bottom should resort to the old `fill_rectangle()`.

target_title: Cell backgrounds drawn at wrong offset

target_title: Cell backgrounds drawn at wrong offset

note.body:
@chergert I'm trying to reverse engineer what you might have had in your mind.

You replaced a `fill_rectangle()` call (which takes pixel coordinates) with a brand new `fill_cell_background()` (which takes row/col coordinates) at one place.

This approach, by its very nature, is not capable of handling sub-cell coordinates, i.e. smooth vertical scrolling (partial top row) in our case.

Here I can see two possibilities. One is that `m_draw` is supposed to render the entire top row, and then this work canvas will be placed on top of the actual canvas with a slight vertical offset. This, however, would need further code modifications at many-many (chpe cross-posted at this exact moment :)) other places. So I'd rule out this possibility.

The other is that `fill_cell_background()` needs to handle the partial row, i.e. needs a pixel vertical offset, and it was a simple oversight from you that you didn't think of this possibility. That is, its API is not flexible enough. But once it takes a pixel offset vertically, taking a cell offset horizontally would make it a truly weird API. It should then take both offsets as pixel, for code symmetry and cleanness. And once we're here, I don't see the point in this wrapper method any more. I'd just remove it altogether and revert to using `fill_rectangle()`.

target_title: crash on mouse press

note.body:
I think I might have found it... or at least found one place where things can go wrong.

> there's one more possibility that I can see: `m_ringview` is outdated but incorrectly marked as valid, the first and last displayed rows have changed since then

Yup, it's along these lines.

---

In `Terminal::set_size()` we call `m_ringview.invalidate()` only if the logical terminal size, i.e. expressed in whole rows and columns (rounding downwards), changes.

With per-pixel scrolling (partial row at the top of the window), combined with no geometry hints (as typically in gtk4), it's possible to slightly increase the window height, keeping the number of logical rows the same, yet make one more visual row partially enter at the bottom. This doesn't result in the invalidation of the ringview, even though it really needs to be updated with one more row.

(From the user's point of view, this might be a larger opaque resize, it's just that VTE sees a series of small ones.)

A quick and totally okay fix to this could (and should) be to move the ringview invalidation out of the big `if` branch (`set_size()`'s second half), make it happen all the time when the widget is resized. (Speaking of which, I guess we should do the same for the following few lines as well: invalidate the UI, the regex matches, maybe emit a11y text modified too (although I have no idea how we handle non-integer scroll offsets and partial rows in a11y).)

---

Back to ringview invalidation, for a bit of code health / consistency:

At many places, such as at `hyperlink_check_at()` which we're looking at, the code goes like:

        if (!m_ringview.is_updated())
                ringview_update();

Arguably it's usually a tad bit cheaper, but in turn less safe than the second approach will be: if the ringview incorrectly remained marked as updated, although essential properties have changed (like the number of lines increased by 1, as in our current case), it remains broken.

At other places, such as e.g. `draw_rows()`, the condition is skipped and the code is simply:

        ringview_update();

This is arguably a tad bit slower, but is more robust. The implementation of `ringview_update()` begins with a lots of `set_*()` methods, setting all the essential parameters of the ringview (e.g. which lines it covers). All these `set_*()` methods do mark the ringview as invalid if the property actually changes. Finally, the last `m_ringview.update()` call updates the ringview if it's invalid.

This is still not a forced update: if the text changes but accidentally isn't marked so, it won't update (which shortcut is essential for good performance). But it guarantees to update if any of the metadata changes. So I guess that using this shorter form in `hyperlink_check_at()` would have saved us. Also, since `draw_rows()` uses this short form, I guess the crash is only reproducible within the first UI update frame after the resize, making it pretty rare.

Are we okay with unifying the code, making it more robust, and presumably not any measurably slower, by switching to the latter one-liner everywhere?

target_title: crash on mouse press

note.body:
Does Fedora unset / leave unset `G_DISABLE_ASSERT`? I.e. would we abort on a failing `vte_assert()`, like the out-of-bounds `row` checks [here](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/-/blob/0.78.0/src/ringview.hh?ref_type=tags#L83)?

---

As far as I can see right now:

`hyperlink_check_at()` makes sure that `m_ringview` is updated using our standard pattern:

        if (!m_ringview.is_updated())
                ringview_update();

whereas `ringview_update()` makes sure that `m_ringview` covers the area from the `first_displayed_row()` to (at least) the `last_displayed_row()`.

That is: at this point we either have a correct `m_ringview`, or it is out-of-date but accidentally marked as valid.

In the RingView code, allocing/reallocing/deallocing `m_bidirows` looks good to me, its capacity is always at least the number of required rows (`m_len`) unless it's `pause()`'d, and all its allocated members are always a non-null `new BidiRow()`'ed pointer. The `pause()`/`resume()`/`set_size()` bits seem to always correctly maintain this as an array of non-null pointers.

Next, `hyperlink_check_at()` calls `rowcol_at()` which in turn calls `grid_coords_from_view_coords()` which in turns calls `confine_grid_row(row)` which confines `row` to the `first_displayed_row()`..`last_displayed_row()` interval before we're getting to the `get_bidirow()` lookup that returns NULL.

This seems to be okay to me, and seems to even safely tolerate out-of-widget mouse click coordinates.

Unless I failed to spot a bug in the aforementioned methods that I think I've carefully reviewed and look okay to me, there's one more possibility that I can see: `m_ringview` is outdated but incorrectly marked as valid, the first and last displayed rows have changed since then, the assertions that would fail in `get_bidirow()` are skipped, and an out-of-bounds array lookup just happens to find a pointer's worth of zeros in the memory.

So, if I'm on the right track... who and when can change the scrolling position (or scrolling boundaries?) without invalidating the RingView?? I don't know.

Just wondering: can this, by any chance, be related to overscrolling in GTK4??

note.body:
A random thing I just thought about:

What might be a performance optimization (mostly on slower GPUs, think rpi or postmarketOS) is that you avoid double drawing the background when possible. So if you have a solid background color and a background texture, that's 2 draw passes, and it would be nice if you could avoid the solid color.

GTK with its occlusion culling should be smart enough to avoid the solid color if the texture is opaque. But for transparent textures it can't do that.  
But initializing the background data to the background color and then using `GDK_MEMORY_R8G8B8X8` for the data type would work - at least as long as the background color is opaque.

I have no idea if that's a big gain, but you might be able to benchmark it on software rendering, like llvmpipe or maybe even Cairo.

target_title: Implementing the Kitty keyboard protocol

note.body:
> I feel it's important to explain why the kitty keyboard protocol is truly essential.

I'm open to adding a better keyboard protocol to vte, not necessarily the "kitty" one.

However, the keyboard code in vte is already very convoluted and will need to be modernised/refactored first.

If someone wants to work on it, I'll gladly review patches.

target_title: Implementing the Kitty keyboard protocol

note.body:
I feel it's important to explain why the kitty keyboard protocol is truly essential.

I'm one of the developers of far2l—a port of the Far Manager file manager to Linux.  Since this program was originally developed for the Windows console, it heavily utilizes its advantages, particularly the ability to use any key combinations.

When migrating from Windows to Linux, users look for a familiar UX; they need their favorite applications, not a new operating system.  If we tell them "learn 100 new keyboard shortcuts," they're more likely to stay on Windows than listen to us.

Is it really acceptable that *nix console capabilities in the 21st century are still inferior to those of the ancient Windows 2000 console? This situation needs improvement.

In the far2l project, we came up with a hack that solves the problem under X11: we simply connect to X11 and listen to all keyboard input. This allows us to "refine" the key press information coming into the terminal, "deciphering" what the user actually pressed. A terrible, horribly dirty hack (but it works!)—but better than depriving the user of familiar functionality.

However, with the widespread transition to Wayland, this hack stops working.  What do you think users will do, give up their familiar keyboard shortcuts—or stay on X11?

This is precisely why we need the ability to use any keyboard shortcut in console applications. Not the day after tomorrow, not tomorrow. We needed it yesterday.

Of all the available solutions (far2l terminal extensions, iTerm2 raw keyboard protocol, win32-input-mode, and kitty keyboard protocol), the kitty protocol is the most suitable for UNIX-like operating systems. It's designed with backward compatibility in mind, and adapting terminals to support it is straightforward. Look at this code example. This is a reference implementation of basic kitty protocol support that I made as an example for Windows Terminal developers.  It's only 196 lines of code: https://gist.github.com/unxed/d979fe069039fe075c18eb0218b1f8f5

I hope you will consider these arguments, and together we can bring the console capabilities of UNIX-like operating systems up to par with what the Windows 2000 console offered 24 years ago. I'll be happy to answer any questions if anyone takes this on.  Thank you in advance!

target_title: 0.78.0 does not build with llvm libc++

note.body:
C++17 is 7 years old, so it's quite unfortunate that libc++ [doesn't support it yet](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pull/91651).

> 0.76.x works ok with clang + libc++ Whats the wayout here ?

Sevel possibilities:
* Use libstdc++ (best)
* Comment out the code (not recommended)
* Add code to use `g_ascii_strtod()` if `from_chars` isn't available. I don't like this because AFAIK from_chars is stricter in which input syntax it accepts, which would lead to an unwanted skew in the accepted inputs between normal vte and vte on libc++.
* Use [fast_float](https://github.com/fastfloat/fast_float) as a subproject (or import the headers directly)
* Keep using vte 0.76.

More ideas?
